title-group.article-title: Stability, survival, patient satisfaction, and cost-minimization of CAD/CAM versus conventional multistranded fixed retainers in orthodontic patients: a 2-year follow-up of a two-centre randomized controlled trial

sec.title: Background
sec.p: CAD/CAM (computer-aided design/computer-aided manufacturing) fixed retainers (FRs) as an alternative to multistranded FRs to maintain orthodontic treatment outcome.

sec.title: Objectives
sec.p: The primary aim was to compare CAD/CAM versus conventional multistranded FRs in terms of stability until 2 years. Secondary outcomes were failure rates, patient satisfaction, and cost-minimization.

sec.title: Trial design
sec.p: 2-arm parallel, two-centre randomized controlled trial.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: Patients were randomized to CAD/CAM or conventional FRs in both arches, in a 1:1 ratio and blocks of four. Allocation concealment was secured by using sequentially numbered envelopes. Patients were blinded. FRs were bonded at the end of treatment, and patients were recalled after 12 and 24 months. First-time retainer failures were recorded and digital impressions were taken. Arch widths and lengths, as well as Little’s Irregularity Index (LII), were measured. Additionally, patients answered satisfaction questionnaires. Linear mixed models were applied for measurements and patient satisfaction. Survival analyses were estimated with Kaplan–Meier curves, along with Cox-regression modelling. Cost-minimization analysis was undertaken.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: One hundred and eighty-one patients were randomized (98 in Centre 1, and 83 in Centre 2): 90 in CAD/CAM and 91 in conventional group. One hundred and fifty three patients attended T24 follow-up. There were no significant differences in LII and arch dimensions between groups for failure-free patients. Within 24 months, 34% maxillary CAD/CAM FRs and 38% maxillary conventional FRs failed, along with 42% mandibular CAD/CAM FRs and 40% mandibular conventional FRs, with no significant difference in survival between groups (hazard ratios conventional to CAD/CAM: maxillary arch: 1.20 [P = 0.46], mandibular arch: 0.98 [P = 0.94]). There were no significant differences in patient satisfaction between groups. No harms were observed. Cost-minimization analysis showed that CAD/CAM FRs were slightly cheaper than conventional FRs.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: There were no clinically significant differences in LII, arch widths, and lengths between CAD/CAM and conventional FRs after 24 months. There were no differences in failures and patient satisfaction between groups. CAD/CAM FRs were slightly cheaper than conventional FRs.

sec.title: Trial registration
sec.p: ClinicalTrials.gov NCT04389879.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Maintaining a stable result after orthodontic treatment remains one of the biggest challenges in orthodontics. Tooth position may change after treatment due to periodontal, gingival, and occlusal factors as well as normal growth and dentofacial ageing, with unpredictable and variable magnitude of movement [1]. To maintain the achieved clinical outcome, on completion of orthodontic treatment, most of the patients are provided with some type of retainer to resist post-treatment tooth position change.

There is insufficient high-quality evidence to distinctly demonstrate which is the best type of orthodontic retention regime [2]. There are primarily two options for orthodontic retention, either removable retainers or fixed retainers (FRs). Randomized controlled trials comparing FRs and removable retainers have not conclusively proved one type of retention protocol to be superior to the other [3–7]. Previously, it has been shown that over time patient adherence with removable retainers significantly drops [3], thereby resulting in potentially worse long-term retention compared to FRs. Patients seem to prefer FRs because they require less compliance [4] and are more comfortable to wear compared to removable retainers [4, 6].

Since the benefits of long-term orthodontic retention have been identified [8], there has been an increased use of FRs [9]. However, it is important to acknowledge that the use of FRs is frequently associated with diverse complications, such as bond failure and wire fracture, potential for adverse effects on dental and periodontal health, unwanted tooth movement with the FR in situ, and adverse effects on general health [10]. It is unclear which is the best type of FR to minimize the occurrence of various complications, while also offering reliable retention and being cost-effective and comfortable to wear to the patients [11].

In recent years, FRs employing computer-aided design and manufacturing (CAD/CAM) technology have emerged as potential alternatives to conventional handcrafted retainers. These CAD/CAM FRs have been considered advantageous because they might offer better clinical effectiveness due to their precision fit, potential for avoidance of occlusal interferences, and possibly improved passive fitting [12]. Several studies have evaluated the clinical effectiveness of CAD/CAM FRs, however, only in the mandibular arch and mainly in short term [13–17]. Thus, it remains unclear whether CAD/CAM FRs might present better longer-term clinical effectiveness than conventional handcrafted retainers when used in both arches.

To our knowledge, this is the largest randomized controlled trial (RCT) assessing stability, failure rate, patient satisfaction, and cost-minimization of CAD/CAM nitinol FRs versus multistranded (MS) stainless steel FRs in both arches. Further, it is also one of the largest RCTs about FRs in general. The present article presents results from an ongoing RCT over a 24-month follow-up period.

sec.title: Objectives and hypotheses
sec.p: The aims of this RCT were to assess and compare the clinical effectiveness of CAD/CAM versus conventional MS FRs in terms of post-treatment stability (primary outcome), failure rate, patient satisfaction, and cost-minimization (secondary outcomes) during a 2-year period. The null hypothesis was that CAD/CAM FRs exhibit no significant differences compared to MS FRs in terms of stability, failure rate, patient satisfaction, and cost-minimization.

sec.title: Trial design and any changes after trial commencement
sec.p: The present study is a two-centre, two-arm, parallel, RCT with a 1:1 allocation ratio. No changes arose after trial commencement.

sec.title: Participants, eligibility criteria, and settings
sec.p: The sample characteristics were as previously described [18]. Patients treated at two postgraduate orthodontic clinics (Section of Orthodontics, Department of Dentistry and Oral Health, Aarhus University, Denmark and Department of Orthodontics, Institute of Clinical Dentistry, Faculty of Dentistry, University of Oslo, Norway), who were close to end of their orthodontic treatment, were asked to participate. Patient enrolment started on 15 January 2019 and finished on 15 June 2019 in Centre 1 (Aarhus University) and started on 15 May 2019 and finished on 7 October 2020 in Centre 2 (University of Oslo). The following inclusion criteria were applied:

list-item.p: Good general health
Age range 12–25 years old
Presence of all maxillary and mandibular anterior teeth with normal shape and size
Completion of treatment with full fixed appliance.

sec.p: There was no restriction to initial malocclusion. The following exclusion criteria were applied:

list-item.p: Patients with cleft lip and/or palate or any other craniofacial syndrome.
Patients with compromised oral hygiene or periodontal disease.
Patients who had orthognathic surgery.
Lingual appliance treatments.
Enamel hypoplasia, fluorosis, active caries, restorations, or fractures in the anterior teeth.
Patients who had separate arch debondings with a difference of more than 2 months in-between jaws.
Re-treatments.
Patients who were assigned to another retention protocol due to their initial malocclusion.

sec.p: Recruited patients (or a parent/guardian in the case of a minor patient) received oral and written information about the study. Patients who agreed to participate signed an informed consent before debonding. The study was approved by the Health Research Ethics Committee-Central Jutland, Denmark (case number: 1-10-72-266-18), and by the Regional Committees for Medical and Health Research Ethics, Norway (case number: 2018-1655).

sec.title: Preparation of fixed retainers
sec.p: Intraoral scanning and laboratory procedures:

list-item.p: At the last appointment before debonding, patients had supra-gingival debridement followed by intraoral scanning (Trios 3, 3Shape, Copenhagen, Denmark) of both arches with bite registration.

Intraoral scans for CAD/CAM FRs were sent to CA Digital lab via 3Shape Communicate® (Copenhagen, Denmark), and intraoral scans for conventional MS FRs were sent to the Departments’ internal laboratories.
Laboratory work:

CAD/CAM FRs: 0.014 × 0.014-inch rectangular nitinol retainers (Memotain, CA Digital, Hilden, Germany) were digitally designed using OnyxCeph 3D Pro software (Image Instruments, Chemnitz, Germany). Thereafter, they were custom cut from a nitinol sheet, electro-polished, and equipped with a silicone transfer key to facilitate positioning [19]. The utilized CAD/CAM FRs have been described previously [18].

Conventional MS FRs: 0.0215-inch six-stranded stainless steel (G&H, Franklin, Indiana, USA) retainers were crafted by the same dental technician at each centre. The wire was shaped to passively fit to the lingual surfaces of maxillary and mandibular anterior teeth on the model, without heat treatment and avoiding occlusal contacts. A silicone transfer key was prepared for each retainer, as previously described [18].

sec.title: Bonding of fixed retainers
sec.p: In each centre, one operator bonded all FRs (T0), as previously described [18].
An intraoral scan (Trios 3) and intraoral photographs were taken at the end of the bonding procedure (T0).
After debonding patients received a maxillary removable vacuum-formed retainer (Essix™ C+) to be worn at night-time.

sec.title: Follow-ups
sec.p: Patients were recalled after 1, 3, and 6 months, as previously reported [18], as well as after 12 (T12), and 24 (T24) months. At all visits, a clinical examination together with an acquisition of intraoral scans and intraoral photographs was performed. The pattern of FR failure was recorded as follows: (i) debonding at enamel–composite interface: one or more bonding sites detached from the enamel surface but the FR still in situ; (2) debonding at wire–composite interface: one or more bonding sites detached from the wire surface but the FR still in situ; (iii) wire fracture: the FR fractured at one or more sites; (iv) complete detachment from all teeth: all bonding sites of the FR detached; and (v) removed by the clinician: the FR was completely removed due to relapse or unexpected post-treatment changes. For each failure, the affected teeth were registered. Patients were asked to contact the clinic as soon as possible when they encountered any problems or concerns.
In addition, at T12, the patients were requested to answer a 5-item visual analogue scale (VAS) regarding comfort/satisfaction with the FRs. The VAS used has been described previously [18].

sec.title: Outcomes (primary and secondary) and any changes after trial commencement
sec.p: The primary outcome was the post-treatment stability. The secondary outcomes were retainer failures, patient satisfaction, and cost-minimization. No changes were made after trial commencement.

sec.title: Post-treatment stability
sec.p: As previously mentioned, intraoral scans were taken at T0, T12, and T24. The resulting digital models were measured at T12 and T24. The T0 models had been measured previously [18]. One operator, previously calibrated, in each centre, measured the Little’s Irregularity Index (LII), and the maxillary and mandibular arch widths and lengths using the Ortho Analyzer software (3Shape). The reference points for the measurements of arch widths and lengths have been described previously [18]. The LII was also evaluated before orthodontic treatment to ascertain baseline characteristics of the patients.

sec.title: Failures
sec.p: The survival time and pattern of FR failure were recorded separately for each arch during the follow-up period. The survival time was calculated from the day of bonding to the day of the first failure event. Only the first failure event was considered for the survival analysis. The date of failure was reported as the day the patient became aware of the problem or alternatively the date the clinician noted the failure when the patient was unaware of the failure. If some patients did not attend the last appointment (T24) but still attended one of the follow-ups, the status observed at their last appointment was taken into consideration for the survival analysis.

sec.title: Patient satisfaction
sec.p: Patient satisfaction was determined at T12, using the same questionnaire administered at 1-month (T1) and 6-month (T6) follow-ups [18]. The VAS questionnaires were sent by email to the patients who did not attend the appointments.

sec.title: Sample size calculation
sec.p: The previously described sample size was determined based on the primary outcome (post-treatment stability) [18]. To express a difference of 1.5 mm in LII [20] between both groups and assume that the standard deviation of LII is 3 mm [21], the study required 63 subjects per group with a power of 80% and a significance level of 5%. To account for a possible dropout rate of 40%, the sample size was increased to a total of 90 subjects per group.

sec.title: Randomization
sec.p: The randomization method has been described previously [18]. In summary, the patients were randomized into blocks of four following an online computer-generated sequence (randomization.com) to either CAD/CAM FR or conventional MS FR. Allocation concealment was secured by using sequentially numbered, opaque, and sealed envelopes.

sec.title: Blinding
sec.p: Patients were blinded but blinding of the operator was not possible due to the nature of the intervention. Blinding of the outcome assessor regarding stability and failures was not possible due to the evident differences between the FRs but blinding the assessor for patient satisfaction was secured by removing patient identifying information from the completed forms.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Data collection and management were performed employing REDCap (Research Electronic Data Capture) (Centre 1) and TSD (services for sensitive data) (Centre 2). All analyses were conducted utilizing Stata Statistical Software (Release 16. College Station, StataCorp, TX, USA). For arch dimensions and LII, each individual measurement was modelled by a linear mixed model with an unstructured marginal covariance pattern to induce a correlation between repeated measures on the same patient [22]. The survival analyses were done by the Kaplan–Meier curves separately for the maxillary and mandibular FRs, along with a Cox-regression modelling with the Breslow method for ties to assess predictors for FR survival. VAS results were adjusted for age, gender, randomization group, and time, in addition to modelling by a linear mixed regression model, but with repeated measures on the same patient. All linear mixed models included a Kenward–Roger adjustment for the denominator degrees of freedom. To maintain the study-wise significance level at 5%, a one-step Bonferroni multiplicity adjustment was employed for modelling multiple individual outcomes. For example, when modelling the 5 questions in the VAS questionnaire, the individual significance level for each VAS outcome was revised down to 1%.

sec.title: Error of the method
sec.p: Inter-examiner reliability of the analyses of digital models and test–retest reliability of the VAS questionnaires has been performed and described previously [18].

sec.title: Calculation of cost-minimization
sec.p: The cost-minimization analysis was performed using direct costs only, given that indirect costs, defined previously as loss of school or working hours [23], were the same for both FR groups. The direct costs included material costs, chair time costs, and salary for the orthodontists. The cost analysis was performed only for Norway as it is expected to be similar to Denmark. One CAD/CAM FR costs 111 Euro (€), and one conventional MS FR costs 126 €, both prices including shipping. The cost of chair time (premises, dental equipment, maintenance, cleaning) was calculated as 125 € per hour (hr), based on a previous study published in 2013 (23) and taking into account an inflation rate of 28% from 2013 to 2023 (source: worlddata.info). The average annual salary for a Norwegian orthodontist working for the public dental health services was estimated as 113 000 € (source: dental health service’s competence centres). The time for FR bonding was considered similar for both groups and was estimated as 6.7 minutes (min) per FR based on a previous study using a similar FR bonding technique with a transfer key [24]. The cost calculation for a complete FR detachment from all teeth was based on 5-min clinical working time for composite removal, plus 6.7-min clinical working time for the FR rebonding procedure. It did not include the cost for a new FR as it was assumed that the existing completely detached FR could be rebonded. The cost calculation for FR debondings at the enamel– or wire–composite interfaces was based on 10 min clinical working time for composite removal and rebonding. The cost calculation for FR wire fracture was based on 5-min clinical working time for composite removal, 5 min for scanning, plus 6.7 min for the FR rebonding procedure. The cost calculation for FR wire fracture included a new FR cost only for the conventional group as the CAD/CAM retainer comes with a 24-month wire fracture warranty.

sec.title: Participant flow
sec.p: A total of 357 subjects were assessed for eligibility (207 in Centre 1 and 150 in Centre 2), as shown in the CONSORT flow diagram (Fig. 1). One hundred and eighty-one patients were randomized (90 to the CAD/CAM group and 91 to the conventional group).

caption.p: CONSORT diagram depicting the flow of the patients through the trial.

sec.p: One hundred and fifty-three patients attended the T24 appointment (81 patients in the CAD/CAM and 72 in the conventional group) and were considered for the 24-month evaluation (Fig. 1). Patients who did not show up within 3 months from the planned T24 appointment were no longer considered for the 24-month evaluation.

sec.title: Baseline data
sec.p: Baseline characteristics of groups have been described previously [18]. The baseline characteristics of the patients in each group were comparable regarding gender, age, treatment modality, and LII.

sec.title: Main outcome: stability
sec.p: There was no significant difference in LII, maxillary, and mandibular arch lengths and widths (inter-canine, inter-premolar, and inter-molar distances) between the groups both at 12-month and 24-month follow-ups, for the failure-free patients (Table 1). In the CAD/CAM group, there was a significant increase in LII both at the 12-month (mean difference: 0.3 mm; 95% confidence interval: 0.1 mm, 0.5 mm; P = 0.002) and the 24-month (mean difference: 0.4 mm; 95% confidence interval: 0.1 mm, 0.6 mm; P = 0.000) follow-ups (Table 1). In the maxillary arch, there was a significant decrease in inter-molar width (mean difference: −0.9 mm; 95% confidence interval: −1.5 mm, −0.3 mm; P = 0.000) and arch length (mean difference: −0.8 mm; 95% confidence interval: −1.3 mm, −0.3 mm; P = 0.000) in the conventional group at 24-month follow-up (Table 1). In the mandibular arch, there was a significant decrease in arch length (mean difference: −1.1 mm; 95% confidence interval: −1.8 mm, −0.5 mm; P = 0.000) in the CAD/CAM group at 24-month follow-up (Table 1). No unexpected post-treatment changes were detected in either group at 12-month and 24-month follow-ups.

caption.p: Arch dimensions and LII for the failure-free subjects: Adjusted means, 95% confidence interval (CI) and P values. Maxilla: N = 115, mandible: N = 107

fn.p: UIC: upper inter-canine distance; UIP: upper inter-premolar distance; UIM: upper inter-molar distance; UAL: upper arch length; LIC: lower inter-canine distance; LIP: lower inter-premolar distance; LIM: lower inter-molar distance; LAL: lower arch length; LII: Little’s Irregularity Index.
*P value < 0.0056 (significance level for individual outcomes lowered by one-step Bonferroni multiplicity adjustment to 0.05/9 = 0.0056).

sec.title: Secondary outcome: failures
sec.p: Within 24 months, in the maxillary arch, 31 out of 90 CAD/CAM retainers (34%) and 35 out of 91 conventional retainers (38%) failed (total maxillary failures: 66), whilst in the mandibular arch, 38 out of 90 (42%) CAD/CAM retainers, and 36 out of 91 (40%) conventional retainers failed (total mandibular failures: 74). There was no statistically significant difference in survival between the two groups. The hazard ratios are reported in Table 2. The male patients were 1.7 times more likely to encounter failure in the mandibular arch compared to female patients (hazard ratio male to female: lower arch: 1.74 [P = 0.022]). The Kaplan–Meier survival curves for both groups are presented in Fig. 2. The distribution of the maxillary and mandibular first-time failure patterns in each group are illustrated in Table 3. Bond failure was the most common pattern of failure in both groups and both arches. In the maxillary arch, debonding at either enamel- or wire–composite interface accounted for about a third each, with wire fracture accounting for a quarter of the failures. In the mandibular arch, more than half of the failures were due to debonding at enamel–composite interface, and almost 30% due to debonding at wire–composite interface. The distribution of failures per tooth is shown in Fig. 3. The lower incisors were the most prone teeth to debondings.

caption.p: Hazard ratios for CAD/CAM and conventional FRs.
Distribution of maxillary and mandibular FR failure patterns in each group over the 24 months retention follow-up.
Kaplan–Meier survival curves for the maxillary and mandibular arches according to CAD/CAM and conventional FRs.
Distribution of bond failures per tooth in each group up to 24-month follow-up.

sec.title: Secondary outcome: patient satisfaction
sec.p: One hundred and forty-one patients completed the VAS at T12 follow-up. Patient satisfaction improved significantly at T12 compared to T1 for all questions except question 2 (‘How comfortable is it to clean your teeth together with your FRs?’) (Fig. 4). There was no statistically significant difference between the CAD/CAM and the conventional groups.

caption.p: Patients’ satisfaction VAS changes over time.

sec.title: Secondary outcome: cost- minimization
sec.p: The conventional FRs were approximately 10% more expensive compared to CAD/CAM FRs over a 24-month period (Table 4).

caption.p: Cost-minimization analysis for CAD/CAM and conventional FRs over the 24-month retention follow-up.

tr.th: Risk of failure (number of failures maxilla + mandible/number of patients)

tr.td: 6.7 min* × 2 × (orthodontist salary + chair time per minute)
(5 min** + 6.7 min*) × (orthodontist salary + chair time per minute) × risk of failure
Debonding at enamel– or wire–composite interface
10 min*** × (orthodontist salary + chair time per minute) × risk of failure
(5 min** + 5 min **** + 6.7 min*) × (orthodontist salary + chair time per minute) × risk of failure

td.bold: Total expected cost for 24-month period, per patient

sec.title: Harms
sec.p: No harm was observed.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Fixed retention aims to maintain orthodontic treatment results in the long term. Besides ensuring teeth remain stable in their new position, FRs must keep the teeth in position without doing any harm and should be cost-effective and comfortable to wear to the patients. To our knowledge, the present RCT is the largest one to compare stability, failure rate, patient satisfaction, and cost-minimization of CAD/CAM nitinol FRs versus MS stainless steel FRs in both maxillary and mandibular arches. There was no significant difference in post-treatment stability, failure rate, and patient satisfaction between CAD/CAM and conventional FRs during a 2-year follow-up period. Thus, CAD/CAM nitinol FRs do not seem clinically more effective compared to established conventional MS stainless steel FRs. Still, CAD/CAM nitinol FRs could be more effective in resisting occurrence of unexpected post-treatment changes in long term due to their possible passive fitting and non-deformability. Furthermore, CAD/CAM FRs were slightly cheaper compared to conventional MS FRs handcrafted by a dental technician, over a 2-year follow-up period.

Post-treatment stability in terms of LII and arch dimensions was similar between CAD/CAM and conventional failure-free FRs. Nevertheless, in the CAD/CAM FR group, there was a continuous statistically, but not clinically significant increase in LII from a 0.2 mm mean difference at the 6-month follow-up [18] to 0.4 mm mean difference at the 24-month follow-up. This minor increase in LII might have also induced a statistically significant decrease in mandibular arch length in the CAD/CAM FR group (mean difference: −1.1 mm) at 24-month follow-up, as changes in the amount of incisor irregularity may also affect the changes in arch length [25]. The minor increase in mandibular incisor irregularity and decrease in mandibular arch length in the CAD/CAM FR group could be due to superelastic properties of nitinol material [12] that ensure that natural, physiological changes characterized by gradual increased anterior crowding and decreased arch length are restricted as little as possible [26]. Similarly to our findings, previous studies regarding post-treatment stability in terms of incisor irregularity and arch dimensions have found no statistically significant difference between CAD/CAM nitinol and MS FRs [13, 14, 16, 17].

Over 24 months of follow-up, no unexpected post-treatment changes in terms of torque changes between two adjacent teeth or opposite tipping of contralateral canines with torquing of the whole anterior segment [10] were observed in either group. These unexpected post-treatment changes are rare [27, 28], but often occur after more than 2 years post-treatment [29], and in almost half of the patients [28] may require various types of re-treatment [30].

Failure of FRs is a somewhat common clinical complication and may be due to debondings of the wire from a single tooth to multiple teeth, with the failure happening either at the enamel–composite interface or the wire–composite interface, but also due to wire fracture. The prevalence of failure reported in the literature varies substantially, from 1% [31] to ~50% [32, 33]. In the present study, the failure rate in the maxillary arch was 34% for the CAD/CAM FRs and 38% for the conventional FRs, whereas in the mandibular arch, the failure rate was 42% for the CAD/CAM FRs, and 40% for the conventional FRs. Thus, in line with previously reported data until 3-year post-treatment [13, 14, 17, 18], the present findings indicate that the failure rates for CAD/CAM and conventional FRs were similar over a 2-year post-treatment period. In addition, a study by Kartal and co-authors concluded that CAD/CAM FRs (77% survival rate) and MS FRs (73% survival rate) were similar in terms of survival rates 6 months post-treatment [15]. Alike our previous 6-month post-treatment data [18], the failure rate was lower for maxillary FRs compared to mandibular FRs, notably for CAD/CAM FRs (failure rate: 34% for maxillary CAD/CAM FRs versus 42% for mandibular CAD/CAM FRs). The higher failure rate for the latter might hint that physiological changes regarding incisor irregularity and dental arch dimensions are more pronounced in the mandibular arch and that nitinol material might not withstand age-related tooth position changes.

In the present study, the most common pattern of failure for both groups and both arches was debonding at either the enamel–composite or the wire–composite interface. A similar pattern of failure could be also observed over 6-month follow-up period [18], and thus may reflect the bonding techniques rather than the FRs used. However, wire fractures for maxillary CAD/CAM FRs increased notably from the 6-month follow-up [18] to the 24-month follow-up: from 5 wire fractures up till 11 wire fractures, respectively. This may be related to the more brittle nature of nitinol. Conversely, Gelin and co-authors, comparing CAD/CAM FRs to conventional FRs until 1-year post-treatment, reported no FR fractures and observed a similar proportion of debondings with CAD/CAM FRs compared to conventional FRs [14]. Four other studies comparing CAD/CAM FRs to conventional FRs did not report failure patterns [13, 15–17].

Patient experiences associated with FRs are important, as successful retention is reliant on patient compliance in maintaining optimal oral hygiene and care of FRs over long periods. In the present study, there was no significant difference in patient satisfaction between CAD/CAM and conventional FRs. Further, patient satisfaction improved significantly over time for all questions except question 2 (‘How comfortable is it to clean your teeth together with your FRs?’). Gelin and co-authors, comparing CAD/CAM FRs to conventional FRs, found no difference in overall satisfaction and level of discomfort for the tongue with CAD/CAM vs conventional FRs, but did not investigate cleaning issues [14]. Four other studies comparing CAD/CAM FRs to conventional FRs did not report patient experiences [13, 15–17]. Forde and co-authors have previously reported that patients find FRs in general difficult to clean [4].

In addition to clinical effectiveness and patient experiences, FRs should also be cost-effective. In the present study, the conventional dental technician handcrafted MS FRs were slightly more expensive than CAD/CAM FRs (approximately 10%). It is worth noticing that the conventional MS FRs used in this study were made by the technicians employed at the universities and hence were ‘virtually’ free of charge. The price used in the calculation for the cost-minimization analysis is the average price charged by a private dental technician laboratory in Norway for handcrafting a conventional MS FR. However, a survey of Norwegian orthodontists revealed that almost all orthodontists manufactured the FRs in-house, which might be much cheaper [34]. This means that the presented cost-benefit assessment must be interpreted with caution: The cost of conventional MS FRs manufactured by a dental technician is high in Norway and even surpasses the cost of CAD/CAM technology-produced FRs. Yet, the study by Hu and co-authors comparing CAD/CAM FRs and conventional FRs handcrafted by a dental technician found that CAD/CAM method is more time-efficient than conventional method [35], suggesting that FRs fabricated by CAD/CAM technology could be more cost-effective compared to dental technician handcrafted FRs. Nevertheless, the cost for conventional FRs might be lower if the orthodontist fabricates the conventional FRs in house. In-house manufacturing of retainers also removes the dependency on an external laboratory, possibly generating long waiting times between manufacturing and shipping FRs with potential risk for tooth movement, which could be a drawback of CAD/CAM retainers. Regardless of the context, this article provides a calculator where parameters can be modified in order to perform a customized cost-minimization analysis adapted to specific country or setting conditions. Unfortunately, our cost analysis could not be compared to similar studies, as the previous studies comparing CAD/CAM nitinol FRs to conventional MS stainless steel FRs have not analysed cost-minimization [13–17].

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: In the present study, the CAD/CAM nitinol Memotain® 1.0 FRs were used. After the present study was initiated, an optimized version Memotain® 2.0 has been introduced, which is according to the manufacturer ‘serrated to overcome the sliding effect, designed to fit better at the interdental areas and is assumed to have minimum risk of fracture’. Hence, we could not assess whether Memotain® 2.0 could actually offer better retention to the tooth surface, thus leading to a lower failure rate, specifically at the enamel/wire–composite interface, or reduce the risk of wire fracture.

sec.title: Generalizability
sec.p: One experienced operator at each centre bonded all retainers, which is a strength of the present study. However, this might not reflect the variability of a larger group of clinicians.

list-item.p: There was no statistically significant difference in LII, arch dimensions, failure rate, and patient satisfaction between CAD/CAM nitinol and MS conventional FRs in the maxillary and mandibular arches, during the 24-month retention follow-up.
Within 24 months, 34% of maxillary CAD/CAM FRs and 38% of maxillary conventional FRs failed, along with 42% of mandibular CAD/CAM FRs and 40% of mandibular conventional FRs.
The most common failure pattern in both groups was debonding at the enamel–composite interface.
The CAD/CAM FRs were approximately 10% cheaper compared to conventional MS FRs handcrafted by a dental technician.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The authors express their gratitude to Sandro Leidi for statistical assistance, to Shadi Gera for bonding the FRs in Centre 1, and to Kasper Dahl Kristensen and Peter Stoustrup for facilitating logistics in Centre 1.

sec.p: The authors declare that there is no conflict of interest.

sec.p: This trial was registered on ClinicalTrials.gov (NCT04389879).

sec.title: Data availability
sec.p: The data underlying this article will be shared on reasonable request to the corresponding author.
